page.title: 06BEEF PRODUCTION - DOLPHINTON
page.content: Dolphinton is categorised as a less favoured area. Few pure-bred cattle are kept, most beef cows being crosses of beef and dairy cattle. "Continental" bulls are used, eg. Charolais, Simmental and Linousin. Calves are generally born in Spring and suckle their mothers for about 9 months. Cows/calves are kept at grass till November, and are housed for the winter, either in straw-bedded or slatted sheds. Winter feed is mainly home-grown silage and barley, with hay and roots used on a few farms. Some calves are sold at 1 year old to be fattened mainly in E. Lothian or Aberdeenshire, and some are fattened on the farm of origin. Values Â£300 and Â£500 resp. Main problems with calves are worm infestation and pneumonias, controlled by anthelmintic and antibiotic drugs resp.
